rounds.response:
I have K♠A♣ – top-two over-cards on a 4♠Q♥5♥5♣ board that has paired. So far:

- Flop: I continuation-bet (40 into 40) and got called; board is very coordinated – multiple straight and flush draws.
- Turn: 5♣ pairs the board; sets and two-pair may be out there, over-cards to any draw still have value.

It is checked to me again. I currently only have ace-high, but it beats missed flush or straight draws and may still be best versus busted broadway hands. At the same time, checking or making a small blocker bet are both viable. With 120 in the pot and 910 left behind, deciding between caution and thin value.

I’ll fire a modest second-barrel (around 45–60 chips) to apply pressure but not inflate the pot too much on this paired board. I’ll go with 55.

[Bet 55]

I’m already in the turn with the board reading 5♦ K♠ 9♣ 7♠ and no betting currently open. My hole cards are 8♦ J♥.

Against a single opponent who just check-called the flop and now checked the turn, I have an open-ended straight draw (any 10 or six gives me the nuts) plus a back-door flush possibility. The pot is 160, I have 1 535 behind, and villain just 305. Any bet I make risks putting the short-stack all-in, but denying them a cheap river with so much equity seems correct.

I’ll bet small enough to keep pressure without necessarily ending the hand right now, but large enough to charge any draws they may have. Half-pot (≈80) is reasonable.

[Bet 80]
